column37: Senegal operates a fully launched biometric identity system anchored in the CEDEAO biometric ID card, legally instituted in 2016, and a broader national digital ID program initiated in 2022 under its Digital Strategy 2025 . The system collects extensive biometric data—up to ten fingerprints and facial images—embedded on smart cards and managed by Senegal Numérique, ANSD, and the Ministry of Economy & Digital. Integration efforts are ongoing, notably with universal health insurance and financial KYC. While the system supports regional interoperability within ECOWAS, access gaps remain due to internet penetration challenges. Privacy protections exist under Senegal’s data protection authority, though concerns persist around centralized databases and deportation usage. Technology partners include Iris Corp and Innovatrics.

column37: Afghanistan’s e‑Tazkira is a launched and operational foundational digital identity system, managed by the NSIA under Taliban rule. It is a smart-card based polycarbonate ID with embedded biometric data including fingerprints and iris scans, alongside detailed socio-demographic information. Official rollout began in 2018, and by early 2025, over 14–15 million cards have been issued, including to diaspora through Asan Khedmat centers. While designed for comprehensive integration across banking, SIM registration, voting (when applicable), and public services, it faces major inclusion challenges, especially among women and rural populations. Moreover, the system has been flagged for surveillance risks, corruption in distribution, and concerns over the Taliban’s control of sensitive biometric databases. The legal underpinning comes from the 2013 Population Registration Act and subsequent e‑Tazkira rollout policies.

column37: Since 2009, Albania has issued a biometric national ID card (Letërnjoftim) and biometric passports under a PPP concession led by IDEMIA/ALEAT. The system is mandatory, embedded in EU visa-liberalization processes. Citizens authenticate via fingerprints and facial recognition through their smart cards, mobile OTPs, or PINs. Albania's unified e-government portal, e‑Albania, is administered by AKSHI and leverages these IDs for public services like health, welfare, taxation, and private-sector access (e-signing, SIMs). Biometric IDs are required for voting; about 120,000 non-compliant citizens faced exclusion in the 2025 elections. While adoption is widespread and data protection aligns with EU norms, the system faced minor disruptions from cyberattacks. Technology partners include IDEMIA, Smartmatic, and OSCE across sectors.

column37: Algeria launched its biometric national ID card (CNIBE) in early 2016, under the Ministry of Interior's secure documents directorate. The polycarbonate smart card includes dual chips—one contactless ICAO chip for travel and biometric fingerprint match-on-card to ensure robust identity assurance. Issued free of charge to all adults, over 16 million cards had been distributed by 2019. The ID is mandatory for elections, KYC, e-government access, welfare, education, and serves as a passport/travel document. The system aligns with ICAO standards and integrates within national public services, though public privacy frameworks continue evolving. The project, supported by Thales/Gemalto under the Digital Algeria 2030 strategy, features modern e-signature and security measures

column37: Andorra has initiated a foundational digital identity portfolio, a hybrid mobile/web-based digital wallet piloted from 2024, managed by OSCEPA and Andorra Digital. It enables citizens to store verifiable credentials—like ID cards, permits, and diplomas—and share them securely with public and private entities under user-controlled consent. Designed in alignment with eIDAS 2, it supports cross-border interoperability, particularly within the EU. Authentication relies on digital certificates and mobile PINs, with no biometric component. Early researches target use cases in banking, social services, taxation, healthcare, education, and identity verification. The system is supported by strong EU-style data protection frameworks, developed with Var Group. Public rollout continues with gradual scaling.

column37: Angola has implemented a biometric national ID (Bilhete de Identidade) managed by the Ministry of Justice, rolling out modern smart-card and LaserCard optical credentials since around 2009–2010. The card stores up to ten fingerprints and a photo, supporting both offline and online verification via chip or secure printing. With around 6.5 million cards issued by 2017, the country is continuing enrollment via fixed centers and mobile units to reach its full adult population. The ID is mandatory, linked to voter registration, KYC for banking and SIMs, and early stages of integration into digital public infrastructure supported by a $200M Indian credit line. While it brings authentication convenience, approximately 12 million Angolans remain unregistered, and efforts continue across rural areas. Angola’s program is backed by HID Global, India, and private-sector verifiers like Dojah.

column39:
The second phase of DELPHI (Delivery vs. Payment Hybrid Initiative), a joint project between the OeNB and several commercial banks, is being run this year with the aim of exploring advanced functionality and structural options for a wholesale CBDC.
The first phase, run between October 2020 and June 2021, tested delivery versus payment for bonds via the blockchain. DELPHI is pegged directly to the euro. No decision has yet been made to implement a wholesale CBDC.
Key motivates for the project include desires for instant payment settlement, as well as fewer intermediaries and lower costs in the settlement process.

column37: In April 2020, China became the world's first major economy to pilot a digital currency. As of February 2022, the pilot  has been operational in 11 regions, including the Olympic venues in Beijing and  Zhangjiakou. During the Olympic Games, both foreign and domestic visitors could use the e-CNY wallet.
column39:
In 2017, as a part of a wider push to develop its high-technology sectors, China launched a project called Digital Currency Electronic Payments, or “DCEP." Since then, Chinese officials have said the digital currency will have “controllable anonymity," allowing the government to provide a level of privacy while also regulating against money laundering and other illicit activity. In April 2020, China piloted the digital currency in four cities, allowing commercial banks to run internal tests like conversions between cash and digital money, account-balance checks, and payments. In August, the pilot program expanded to 28 major cities, across 10 regions. As of June 2021, the PBOC announced that more than 20.87 million personal and 3.51 million corporate digital yuan wallets had been opened, with a total transaction value of around $5.39 billion. According to October 2021 numbers, 123 million individual wallets and 9.2 million corporate wallets had been opened with transaction volume of 142 million and transaction value of RMB 56 billion (equivalent to approximately $8.8 billion). Reports from early 2022 indicate that more than 260 million wallets have been opened.

The PBOC has also begun laying the groundwork for the e-CNY to be used in cross-border transactions. Aiming for broad circulation in 2022, the People’s Bank of China and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority have begun ‘technical testing’ for cross-border use of the digital yuan in Hong Kong. In 2021, China announced its plan to test it with foreign visitors at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics. In February 2021, an announcement was made that the PBOC joined central banks from Thailand, the United Arab Emirates, and Hong Kong to explore a cross-border wholesale CBDC project named Multiple Central Bank Digital Currency (m-CBDC) Bridge. In July 2021, the PBOC announced that foreign travelers to China will be able to use e-CNY even without domestic bank accounts if they provide their passport information. The e-CNY offers offline functionality and different levels of anonymity standards corresponding to transaction and balance limits. In February 2022, visitors to the Olympic Games venues in Beijing and Zhangjiakou were able to use the software e-CNY application and the hardware e-CNY card, and daily transactions during the Games were around "a couple of million RMB" or over $300,000.

column39: The Central Bank of Denmark explored the viability for a national digital currency (E-krone) in 2016 and 2017. In its December 2017 report, the Danish Central Bank concluded that "the potential benefits of introducing central bank digital currency for households and businesses in Denmark would not match the considerable challenges which this introduction would present." Citing Denmark's existing secure and effective payment infrastructure, the report noted that the efficiency gains from a CBDC does not outweigh the risks of financial instability that a CBDC can lead to the risk of systemic bank runs.

column37: The Bank of France has played a significant role in testing the potential for a digital euro. Several experiments using a digital euro have been conducted in the past few years in collaboration with the ECB, BIS, Monetary Authority of Singapore, and private sector banks.
column39: In May 2020, the Bank of France successfully experimented with using CBDC – the digital euro – through blockchain technology. The experiment entailed testing a sale of securities and was run by Société Générale Forge. Nearly a year later, in late April 2021, the Bank of France collaborated with Société Générale Forge and the European Investment Bank (EIB) to use CBDC to settle digital bonds issued by the EIB via blockchain. The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) Innovation Hub, Banque de France and Swiss National Bank launched Project Jura that, together with a private sector consortium led by Accenture, will conduct an experiment using wholesale CBDC (wCBDC) for cross-border settlement on a distributed ledger technology (DLT) platform. On June 18, the Bank of France successfully conducted a wholesale CBDC experiment with SEBA Bank, as part of the experimental program launched in March 2020. On July 8, the Bank announced successful completion of a cross-border payment experiment with the Monetary Authority of Singapore that used JP Morgan’s Onyx unit. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

column39: At the start of 2020, the German crypto law came into effect. In October 2020, Burkhard Balz, a German politician and executive board member of the country's central bank, said that Germany is looking into alternative digital payment solutions that would prevent the undesirable implications of using CBDCs. To that end, the Bundesbank tested a blockchain-based distributed ledger for electronic securities that would negate the need for CBDCs in March 2021. Thus, the bank is looking into using blockchain technology and smart contracts in tandem with conventional forms of payment. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

column39: In mid-2019, a government panel recommended banning all private cryptocurrencies, with a jail term of up to 10 years and heavy fines for anyone dealing in digital currencies. The panel did, however, ask the government to consider the launch of an official government-backed digital currency in India, to function like bank notes through the RBI. In February 2021, the RBI released a report describing the pros and cons of a digital currency. Although they acknowledged the potential financial inclusion benefits, they also claimed introduction of a CBDC could lead to disintermediation in the banking sector. In March 2021, RBI Governor Shri Shaktikanta Das noted, “As the underlying technology is still developing, we are exploring ways for a clear, safe and legally certain settlement finality, which is most crucial for a secure and efficient payment system.” In July 2021, the RBI announced that it considering a series of pilot studies for an eventual “phased” rollout of a CBDC. In early 2022, India's Finance Minister, Nirmala Sitharaman announced that the "digital rupee" will be introduced by 2022-23, and will be  backed by the Reserve Bank of India. She cited the benefits offered by digital currencies through faster payments system and efficient currency management options.  She did not clarify the underlying technology for the CBDC, and said it could be based on blockchain or other technology. The new budget for the year 2022-23 also levied at 30% on private cryptocurrencies.

column37: In May 2021, Governor Perry Warjiyo of the Bank Indonesia (BI) announced that Indonesia would be launching a digital rupiah currency. It is currently in the process of determining which platform to utilize and how the CBDC can be leveraged to meet its policy priorities.
column39: Bank Indonesia, like many other central banks, has been influenced by the rise of cryptocurrencies and will continue to monitor the space. However, the bank has outlawed the use of cryptocurrencies for payments, fearing their destabilizing effects and use in illicit activity. Regarding this issue, former finance minister Chatib Basri stated the central bank needed a digital currency to counter the circulation of cryptocurrencies. In May 2021, the BI Governor confirmed that they would pursue the launch of a digital rupiah in light of the increasing trend toward digital payment mechanisms. The digital currency will be regulated in the same way cash-based transactions are, and BI is currently working on creating the necessary regulatory infrastructure. The official timeline for release has yet to be publicly announced.

column37: The Central Bank of Iran and the Iranian government have been jointly working on developing a national digital currency to circumvent economic sanctions imposed by the United States and facilitate cross-border transactions. In December 2019, Iranian President Hassan Rouhani even called for a Muslim cryptocurrency to cut dependence on the dollar.
column39: After the United States’ withdrawal from the Iran Nuclear Deal and reimplementation of sanctions in 2018, Iran began to actively pursue the development of a national digital currency. In July of 2018, Alireza Daliri, the head of investment affairs for Iran’s Science and Technology Department, said over the next three months they would integrate blockchain technology with the central bank for implementation of a cryptocurrency across domestic banks. While it does not appear that Iran has issued a rial-backed digital currency, reports indicate that a gold-backed cryptocurrency has been launched in collaboration with Kuknos Company and four Iranian banks. Titled PayMon, it is intended to tokenize bank assets and properties. Notably, Iran has also sought cooperation with Russia and Armenia by signing a trilateral blockchain agreement.

column37:
Although the Bank of Israel has yet to commit to the issuance of a CBDC, it announced in May 2021 that it would accelerate its research on the topic.
The Bank also publicly released a draft model for what the digital shekel would look like in order to promote professional discussion. 
In June, the Bank’s Deputy Governor announced that a preliminary pilot test had already been conducted.
column39: The Bank of Israel has been considering the issue of a digital shekel since 2017. In November 2018, a team from the Bank of Israel released a report that recommended holding off on issuing a digital currency in the near future. In May 2021, the Bank published a report titled, “A Bank of Israel Digital Shekel – Potential Benefits, Draft Model, and Issues to Examine.” In the report, they announced they would accelerate their research and development efforts on a digital currency. Although, they clearly specified they have not committed to the issuance of a CBDC, they are laying the groundwork for eventual CBDC preparedness. Next steps involve the creation of a CBDC steering committee to explore the topic further. In June, Bank Deputy Governor Andrew Abir announced that a pilot had already been conducted, but that he estimated the chance of an Israeli CBDC launch at less than 50%.

column37: In late 2020, the Italian Banking Association (ABI) announced ongoing research contributions to the European Central Bank's (ECB) work on the digital euro, though the Bank of Italy has not mentioned any specific involvement.
column39: In June 2020, the ABI announced interest in being involved with digital euro development. In a previous initiative called Project Spunta, more 100 of the association's banks joined to develop blockchain technologies to improve automated reconcialiation interbank accounts. Much of the same team will be involved in the digital euro research, focusing on technical feasibility and use cases enabled by distributed ledger technology. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

column37: On 31st December 2021, the Jamaican central bank, Bank of Jamaica (BOJ), announced that it has successfully completed the trial of its central bank digital currency (CBDC). It plans to rollout the CBDC later this quarter.
column39: The BOJ had been working with Ireland-based technology firm eCurrency Mint on the sandbox project. The scope of the pilot was limited to digital wallet providers who indicated readiness to participate within the time frame. The National Commercial Bank (NCB) also came on board to test the range of services that can use the CBDC solution, according to the announcement. The services tested included minting J$230 million (circa $1.5 million) worth of digital currency, issuing CBDCs to wallet providers such as the BOJ’s banking department (J$1 million worth of CBDC to be distributed to staff). The first CBDC issuance to a deposit institution was worth J$5 million, made to NCB. The NCB also onboarded 57 customers who conducted person-to-person, cash-in and cash-out transactions through 37 accounts. This included transactions with small merchants, such as local craft jewelers, footwear designers and fashion and garment boutiques, the BOJ said. The rollout will see a continuation of onboarding existing customers and new customers, allowing two additional wallet providers, who are currently conducting testing, to distribute CBDCs to their customers, and the testing of transactions between customers of various participating wallet providers.

column37: On April 5th 2021, the Bank of Japan announced that it is entering a proof of concept phase to test the technical feasibility of the core functions and features required for a CBDC.

column37: The Governor of the Central Bank of Jordan reports a current study to develop a legal digital currency at the end of Janurary 2022.

In May 2021, the National Bank of the Republic of Kazakhstan announced that it has plans to pilot a CBDC known as the “digital tenge.” It is currently in the process of planning the pilot through a series of research studies and discussions with stakeholders.
column39: In May 2020, Mu Xin, a senior Kazakh government adviser, proposed the introduction of blockchain technology and the digital tenge. This would aim to combat corruption and ensure transparency in the allocation of state budget funds. In June, Kazakhstan adopted a development outline for blockchain and digital technology. Kazakh officials revealed the nation’s digital currency development plan to experts from Russia and China in June 2020. In May 2021, the Kazakhstan central bank announced that it plans to pilot a new legal currency called the “digital tenge.” The bank also laid out a roadmap for the future of the digital currency: in May 2021 they published a report on the digital tenge, this will then be widely discussed before the pilot project begins. Once the pilot concludes, a report will be compiled before a decision is made on whether to launch a full-scale digital tenge project.

column37: The Central Bank of Kenya has started exploring the possibility of introducing a CBDC in Kenya, said CBK Governor Patrick Njoroge in October 2020.
column39: At Georgetown's DC Fintech Week in October 2020, CBK Governor Njoroge noted that the CBK has been in discussion with global players about CBDC and that the push to study CBDCs "comes as a result of mushrooming of private cryptocurrencies."

column37: The Bank of the Lao PDR (BOL) is partnering with Japanese blockchain provider Soramitsu to explore the potential of a CBDC for the country.
column39:
In October 2021, the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) announced the selection of Tokyo-based company Soramitsu to participate alongside the BOL in a study on the possibility of issuing a CBDC in Laos.
The results of the study are as of yet unpublished.
The study is part of a wider push by JICA to support socioeconomic development in Laos.

column37: Lebanon's central bank has been developing a CBDC and announced in November 2020 that they would seek a 2021 debut of the digital currency. So far, no updates have been provided. This project is a move to restore confidence in Lebanon’s banking sector in an effort to fight the country’s economic and financial crises.
column39: Lebanon’s central bank has been considering the idea of a state-run digital currency since at least 2018. Efforts accelerated in 2020 after violent protests and silent bank runs deepened the crisis of Lebanon’s financial system. Faced with a dollar crisis, banks tightened restrictions on foreign currency transactions, with at least one major institution limiting withdrawals to just $400 a month. A plunging Lebanese lira made it almost impossible to transact in the local currency. In June 2020, protestors set fire to the central bank in Tripoli, angry over the collapse of the lira, which would eventually plunge to more than 5,000 lire per dollar before rebounding. The growing confusion over the Lebanese fiat currency triggered a wave of Bitcoin buying among locals, with peer-to-peer marketplaces like Localbitcoins seeing a sharp rise in activity. A main motivator of Lebanon's CBDC project is to create a cashless system that promotes the flow of money, as Lebanese citizens currently store over $10 billion in their homes and the economy relying heavily on remittances from its citizens living abroad.

column37: According to the Bank of Lithuania, the country's digital currency LBCOIN is the world‘s first blockchain-based digital collector coin. Together with its physical version, LBCOIN was issued on 23 July 2020.
column39: As of May 2021, the Bank of Lithuania has released 24,000 collector tokens created using the blockchain technology. When purchasing LBCOIN, buyers get 6 randomly selected digital tokens and upon collecting a token from each of the 6 categories, consumers can redeem a physical silver coin. Tokens are available for purchase and storage on the Bank of Lithuania's e-shop.

column37: Though Macau is building a legal framework for its own CBDC issuance, it is most likely that the SAR will become a testing site for the digital yuan in 2022.
column39:
Licenses for all six of Macau's casino operators expire at the end of 2022, and experts anticipate their renewal being contingent on operators' willingness to "become test beds for the digital yuan."
In April 2021, the Macau government announced plans to conduct a feasibility study for a CBDC and amend laws to regulate the issuance of a virtual legal tender. However, current indications are that, if any CBDC is introduced, it will be the digital yuan and not an "e-Pataca."
The main use of a digital currency in Macau would be to "combat money laundering and tax evasion."

column37: Banky Foiben'i Madagasikara (BFM), the Central Bank of Madagascar, is currently exploring technical implementation of a CBDC called the e-Ariary.
column39:
In August 2021, the BFM announced a Request for Information and Quotation to identify "providers and integrators that can implement a CBDC technical solution."
According to an April 2021 IMF arrangement request, Madagascar will be implementing the e-Ariary "to improve the reliability and the access to the financial system."
The e-Ariary is driven by four main objectives: improved financial inclusion, less costly cash management, stronger monetary sovereignty, and support for innovative payment methods.

column37: In March 2021, the Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) announced that it did not have any immediate plans to issue a CBDC. However, in September 2021, the BNM announced that it would join Project Dunbar, led by the Bank for International Settlements (BIS).
column39: In March 2021, the BNM’s annual report stated that the financial system in Malaysia continues to support the functioning of the economy while meeting the needs of individuals and businesses, adding that it did not have immediate plans to issue a CBDC. In June 2021, statements from the BNM’s Director of Financial Development indicated that the bank was interested in piloting a wholesale CBDC, but was not currently focusing on a retail CBDC. In September 2021, the BNM joined the central banks of Australia, Malaysia, and Singapore in the BIS’s Project Dunbar, aimed at testing the use of CBDCs in international settlements. Results of the project are expected to be published in early 2022.

column37: The Marshall Islands first released their plans for a digital currency named the Marshallese Sovereign (SOV) in February 2018. However, the implementation of a Marshallese CBDC would reduce the country's dependence on US tender, while incorporating more of its unbanked population into the local economy and further integrating the island nation into the global economy. SOV is not a CBDC, as the Marshall Islands does not have a central bank.
column39: In contrast to projects like the Bahamian Sand Dollar or China's digital yuan, the Marshallese SOV will not be a representation of the local fiat currency (USD), but will be an independent coin, in circulation alongside the US dollar. Algorand has said that the SOV supply will be regulated by the government of the Marshall Islands and will be algorithmically fixed to grow at 4% per year. In March 2021, IMF representative Sarah Zhou sounded a voice of caution on the SOV rollout and said that the issuance of the Marshall Islands’ digital sovereign currency as legal tender would “raise risks to macroeconomic and financial stability as well as financial integrity” of the islands, “resulting in a significant drag on the economy.” If issued, the SOV’s launch will be preceded by an 18-to-24-month Timed Release Monetary Issuance, or presale, to gauge liquidity and market interest.

column37: The Central Bank of Mauritius first began exploring a CBDC in November of 2019. The governor of the central bank of Mauritius confirmed in May 2020 that his country would progress in the development of a CBDC. In May 2021, the governor announced plans to launch a pilot program by the end of the year.
column39: In order to facilitate creation of a CBDC, the Mauritian introduced a series of regulatory changes in their Finance Act 2020, including a new definition of a “digital currency,” clarification that the currency can only be issued by the central bank, and guidance that the central bank can determine its denomination, design, form and manner. The Finance Act also provides that currency issued by the central bank, including digital currency, shall be legal tender in Mauritius. Mauritius has already demonstrated familiarity with cryptocurrency, creating a licensing regime for custodians and issuing guidance on security tokens last year.

column37: In April 2022, the Central Bank of Mexico (Banxico) announced revised plans to complete development of its CBDC, the digital peso, by 2025.
column39:
Speaking to the country's Senate in April 2022, Banxico Governor Victoria Rodríquez Ceja mentioned that the digital peso should be completed in three years.
Previously, Banxico had announced via Twitter that it would have a digital currency of its own in circulation by 2024.
Banxico considers a CBDC and its associated infrastructure as an option "of great value to advance financial inclusion in the country.”

With DCash, the Eastern Caribbean has become the first currency union central bank to issue digital cash. The digital currency pilot is available for use by the public on their smartphones. Consumers and merchants can utilize the DCash App or use it through participating financial institutions. Since launching in March, the CBDC has expanded to 3 more territories. Currently it is available in all members of the ECCB except Anguilla.

column37: In February of 2021, the Moroccan Central Bank announced the formation of an exploratory committee to investigate the pros and cons of a digital currency after banning cryptocurrencies four years ago. This committee seeks to determine the advantages and drawbacks a CBDC could have for the Moroccan economy.
column39: Although Morocco has announced the formation of its exploratory committee, the central bank has stated that it will continue to take a cautious approach in analyzing the advantages for the Moroccan economy that a digital currency would bring, given the speculative nature of existing cryptocurrencies. Although Morocco's central bank is not considering releasing a prototype of a digital currency anytime soon, it will coordinate with other authorities within the country about measures to take with respect to other crypto-assets. Moreover, even though Moroccan citizens are still banned from owning or trading Bitcoin, the digital currency industry in the country continues to thrive. In fact, Morocco is regarded as one of the top digital currency markets in Africa.

The Governor also stated that digital currencies "represent the future." The BAM created a council dedicated to researching the implications of a CBDC in February 2021. That research is ongoing.

column39: The Central Bank of the Netherlands (DNB) published a report in April 2020 that weighed the implementation of a possible CBDC. The report outline some of the motivations for a CBDC launch, including declining cash use and the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic. The DNB clarified that the mandate for CBDC issuance falls with the ECB, but stated “If the decision should be taken within the eurosystem to experiment with some more concrete type of CBDC, we are ready to play a leading role. The Netherlands provides a suitable testing ground for such an experiment.” The bank also provided some insight into possible CBDC models. In particular, they argued against the use of DLT for digital currencies, citing risks such as high costs and inefficient use of electricity. Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

The RBNZ is seeking public input on the idea until Dec. 6. It gave no indicative time-line for the introduction of a digital currency but said it would release an outline of the next steps by the end of April 2022.
column39: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) announced on July 7, 2021 that it will begin exploring the concept through a series of public consulations. The RBNZ is exploring a CBDC model that will “work alongside cash as government-backed money.” Assistant Governor Christian Hawkesby cited the decline in physical cash use in New Zealand as one of the motivations behind the RBNZ’s interest in a digital currency. Hawkesby stated, “we need to test our assessment of the issues and proposed approach before developing any firm proposals.”

The fourth phase, involving technical testing, is expected to determine whether further  testing should be conducted with a preferred solution "with the aim of being able to introduce a CBDC."
The research is motivated by "low and falling cash usage application of the precautionary principle."

In April 2019, former Bank Deputy Governor Jameel Ahmad announced that the bank was working on a concept to issue a CBDC by 2025.
According to multiple reports, a CBDC in Pakistan would be aimed at promoting financial inclusion, while also reducing inefficiency and corruption by strengthening the country's commitment to anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing measures.

column37: In February 2022, the Bankgo Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) announced a CBDC pilot program called Project CBDCPh, to be rolled out in the "near term."
column39:
Speaking at a February 2022 conference, BSP Governor Benjamin E. Diokno mentioned that Project CBDCPh followed a 2021 exploratory study and national payment system assessment that identified the feasibility of a wholesale CBDC.
At the conference, Diokno added that implementation a retail CBDC would likely require additional legislation. The news of Project CBDCPh follows the BSP's October 2020 declaration that a CBDC would not be issued until 2023 at the earliest.
Diokno mentioned that the primary benefits of a CBDC would be related to financial inclusion, both via "efficient implementation of wide-scale targeted government cash assistance programs" and "cross-border money transfers."

column37: The Bank of Russia first released a report analyzing a possible ruble-backed CBDC in October 2020. In September 2021, the deputy chairwoman of the Bank of Russia announced that they will start testing the digital ruble with a pilot in January 2022 and that they see no obstacle to its eventual launch. In February 2022, Bank of Russia began testing the digital ruble platform after successfully completing transactions using the prototype platform.
column39: In October 2020 the Bank of Russia announced plans to release a prototype CBDC in 2021. 83% of the feedback the bank had received was in favor of its development. The Bank plans to draft regulatory norms for the currency’s integration in 2022. The proposed digital ruble would be built on a hybrid platform with distributed ledger technology, likely using open-source code. Some Russian banks and fintech companies have expressed concerns that the models proposed are excessively centralized and could harm private banks' business by forcing them to compete with the central bank, while analysts are concerned about the degree of economic control a digital ruble could grant the central bank, possibly including the ability to bar unfavored entities from the Russian economic system. The Bank of Russia has also stated that launching a CBDC will decrease their dependence on the US dollar and potentially help in side-stepping US sanctions. In June 2021, the Bank announced a partnership with 12 banks, including Sberbank, VTB, Gazprombank, and Alfa Bank. In February 2022, the Russian central bank announced that it had created a prototype of the digital ruble platform, and that two partner banks had successfully completed a full cycle of digital ruble transfers through mobile banking applications. The bank also announced a phased development of the pilot, focusing on different features across the testing process. At the end of the testing period, Bank of Russia seeks to create a roadmap for the launch of the digital ruble.

column37: Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates launched a bilateral CBDC pilot project called Project Aber in 2019, and concluded that DLT can successfully facilitate cross-border transactions.
column39: Saudi Arabia first launched Project Aber with the UAE in late 2019. The goal with the project was to look at the feasibility of developing a cross-border digital currency. Project Aber was different from most pilot programs as two central banks and a further three commercial banks from each country were involved in the project. The high-level objectives of Aber were: to research DLT technology and to explore its suitability for such an experiment; to see whether inefficiencies of the existing cross-border payments could be overcome using a CBDC; as well as gaining knowledge and experience in DLT technology and the challenges of deploying a mutualized infrastructure. The project's conclusion in November 2020 confirmed that a cross-border dual issued currency was technically viable and that it was possible to design a distributed payment system that offers significant improvements over a centralized payment system.

column37: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has been a leader in testing CBDCs through its Project Ubin. In 2019, Singapore and Canada conducted the first successful international transaction of CBDCs.
column39: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is discussing the creation of multiple CBDC arrangements to improve speed, cost, and transparency of cross-border payments. As part of Project Ubin, the MAS has developed a prototype multi-currency wholesale settlement network, to enabled the issuance and distribution of different CBDCs on a common network.

column37: Since 2018, the Central Bank of Curaçao and Sint Maarten (CBCS) has been exploring the creation of a CBDC in partnership with Bitt Inc., a Barbados-based fintech company.
column39: In August 2018, the CBCS and the Bitt signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to jointly explore the feasibility of issuing CBDC (Digital Curaçao and Sint Maarten Guilder) for the two nations. In the MOU, Interim Director of the CBDCS Leila Matroos-Lasten noted that the central bank seeks to "address its challenges proactively by exploring the latest technology available, for example, to reduce the level of cash usage within the monetary union, and to facilitate more secure, more [anti-money laundering] and [Know Your Customer] compliant, and more efficient financial transactions in and between Curaçao and Sint Maarten.”

column37: In February 2021, South Africa’s Intergovernmental Fintech Working Group (IFWG) announced the launch of Project Khokha 2, exploring use of the blockchain at the wholesale level in South Africa. In May 2021, the South African Reserve Bank (SARB) announced a feasibility study on use of digital currencies at the retail level, expected to conclude in 2022. In September 2021, SARB announced that it would join Project Dunbar, led by the Bank for International Settlements (BIS).
column39: As part of Project Khokha 2, the IFWG will simulate a real-world trial to explore the use of distributed ledger technology in the financial sector and work on technologies such as tokenized money at the wholesale level. SARB’s separate study of retail digital currency use is designed to investigate the use of an electronic legal tender complement to cash, though the Bank has not yet decided to issue a retail CBDC. In March 2019, SARB invited bids from private companies to develop CBDC infrastructure. However, South Africa's future capacity for financial innovation has been threatened recently by several digital currency start-ups seeking to relocate out of the country, citing unclear regulatory policies and the Mirror Trading scandal that defrauded over 23,000 investors last year. column37: The Spanish central bank is participating in efforts to study the impact of a digital euro on the nation’s financial systems and economy. As of the end of June 2021, the current ruling Spanish Socialist Party proposed the creation of a national digital currency separate from the European Union.
column39: In October 2020, the Spanish central bank, Banco de España, released a strategic plan in outlining its primary goals from 2020 to 2024. In this plan, the bank states that it will investigate the impacts of a digital euro on the Spanish economy and financial system as well as develop digital euro design proposals. In late June 2021, the Spanish Socialist Party (PSOE), the current governing political body, proposed the creation of a national digital currency, separate from the European Union. PSOE presented the proposition to the Spanish Congress to create a national digital currency, ostensibly as a response to decreased usage of physical cash and to promote “the recovery of money as a public good, more stable and under democratic control.” In another statement, PSOE stated that this new digital currency “would end the ‘privilege’ of banks over money,” noting that the project would be achieved “without the nationalization of the banking system or the nationalization of credit.” Note: The ECB is tasked with creating digital euros however individual eurozone countries are contributing to developments for both retail and wholesale euros.

column37: Thailand's Central Bank has been moving forward with its three to five year target for launching a CBDC. After a successful cross-border wholesale pilot with Hong Kong, the central bank is planning to launch a retail CBDC pilot in the second quarter of 2022.
column39: Thailand has postponed the pilot of its domestic retail CBDC to late 2022. The pilot will include 10,000 participants who will test the deposit, transfer and withdrawal functionalities of the wallet. The Central Bank of Thailand began exploring the domestic retail CBDC in 2020, and earlier phases of the project were focused on conditional payments and integration of different business platforms. Since 2021, the Central Bank has been exploring the issuance of the CBDC. It launched Project Inthanon in 2018, which began the testing of a domestic wholesale CBDC. This developed into Project Inthanon-LionRock, a collaboration between Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Central Bank of Thailand which led to a cross-border wholesale CBDC corridor. This is also the origin of mBridge, which scales Inthanon-LionRock project to include China and the UAE, in collaboration with the BIS. The main motivations driving Thailand's pursuit of CBDC are the popularity of private digital currencies and enhancing the country's financial and monetary stability.

column37: In December 2019, the Central Bank of the Bahamas launched the Sand Dollar project on the island of Exuma. After the successful pilot in Exuma, the digital currency fully launched across the country in October 2020. The sand dollar is the first ever nationwide Central Bank Digital Currency in the world. Now, the Central Bank is working on achieving full interoperability between its various wallet providers
column39: In October 2020, the Sand Dollar became the first CBDC in the world to go beyond the pilot stage and achieve an official launch. The digital currency became available for use by all Bahamian citizens upon release, while integration with the commercial banking system has been subject to a gradual rollout. The completion of that integration is now imminent, according to the bank. The motivations for the CBDC pilot include improving financial inclusion and strengthening security against money laundering or illicit economic activities. In its statement announcing Project Sand Dollar, the Central Bank of the Bahamas noted that it will "simultaneously promote the development of new regulations for the digital currency, and strengthen consumer protection, especially around data protection standards" as the pilot in Exuma progresses. The Central Bank is now working on achieving full interoperability between its various wallet providers.

column37: Tunisia's blockchain-based e-dinar, issued by the government's post office, has been in circulation since 2015, without central bank involvement. The Central Bank of Tunisia is exploring several digital finance innovations, including a CBDC.

column37: The United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia launched a bilateral CBDC pilot project called Project Aber in 2019, and concluded that DLT can successfully facilitate cross-border transactions. The UAE is also a member of mCBDC.
column38: The United Arab Emirates is involved in two cross-border pilots, Project Aber and mCBDC.
column39: The United Arab Emirates first launched Project Aber with Saudi Arabia in late 2019. The goal with the project was to look at the feasibility of developing a cross-border digital currency. Project Aber was different from most pilot programs as two central banks and a further three commercial banks from each country were involved in the project. The high-level objectives of Aber were: to research DLT and to explore its suitability for such an experiment; to see whether inefficiencies of the existing cross-border payments could be overcome using a CBDC; as well as gaining knowledge and experience in DLT and the challenges of deploying a mutualized infrastructure. The project's conclusion in November 2020 confirmed that a cross-border dual issued currency was technically viable and that it was possible to design a distributed payment system that offers significant improvements over a centralized payment system. In February 2021, it was announced that the United Arab Emirates will join China, Hong Kong, and Thailand in a joint CBDC cross-border test. This “Multiple Central Bank Digital Currency (m-CBDC) Bridge” will test the use of DLT for foreign currency payments, with the hope of eventually expanding to other Asian nations.

column37: The Central Bank of Uruguay successfully completed a digital currency pilot program in April 2018 to issue, circulate, and test payments in an e-Peso. The pilot ended in 2018 and has been at a standstill since then.
column39: Uruguay’s e-Peso pilot was part of a broader government initiative to promote financial inclusion. The pilot ran for 6 months beginning November 2017, issuing 20 million e-Pesos to 10,000 users. Individuals and businesses could hold 30,000 and 200,000 e-Pesos, respectively, in digital wallets. Transfer took place via mobile phones using text messages or an e-Peso app. 6 institutions were involved in the pilot, both from the public and private sectors. The pilot was considered a success and closed in April 2018 to evaluate results and inform additional design decisions. In particular, officials were evaluating how to manage the stock of digital banknotes in different denominations as well as how to manage the level of anonymity.
